facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 19, 1961, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 404 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 19, 1961, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 404 of 1961.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed the appellant's petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Patna dismissing the appellants petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Nalanda College was founded by a private citizen in 1920.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts of the case are these Nalanda College was founded by a private citizen in 1920.

facts.text: Nalanda College became a degree college in 1945.

anchor.surface_text: It became a degree companylege in 1945 and was affiliated to the Bihar University in 1951.

facts.text: Nalanda College was affiliated to the Bihar University in 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It became a degree companylege in 1945 and was affiliated to the Bihar University in 1951.

facts.text: Mr. D.P. Srivastava, a Government servant, was appointed Principal in March 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In March 1953, Mr. D.P. Srivastava who was a Government servant was appointed its Principal

facts.text: Government withdrew Mr. D.P. Srivastava on February 4, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: but the Government withdrew him on February 4, 1958.

facts.text: Appellant was appointed Principal at extraordinary meeting of Governing Body on February 23, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that at an extraordinary meeting of the Governing Body of the College held on February 23, 1958 the appellant was appointed its Principal

facts.text: University was informed of appellant's appointment as required by University Statutes.

anchor.surface_text: and the University were informed of this appointment as required by the University Statutes

facts.text: Appellant took charge of Principal's office on July 11, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: and he actually took charge of his office on July 11, 1958.

facts.text: Appointment of February 23, 1958 confirmed at meeting on July 27, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: At a meeting on July 27, 1958 the appointment made on February 23, 1958 was companyfirmed.

facts.text: Change in constitution of Governing Body on November 9, 1959; respondent No. 2 became Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: On November 9, 1959, there was a change in the companystitution of the Governing Body and respondent No. 2 became its Chairman.

facts.text: Governing Body at meeting on January 31, 1960 resolved to appoint new Principal; appellant to continue till then.

anchor.surface_text: The Governing Body reconsidered the proceedings of February 23, 1958 and at a meeting on January 31, 1960, the Governing Body resolved to appoint a new Principal.

facts.text: Appellant was present at Governing Body meeting on January 31, 1960 as ex-officio member.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile it decided that the appellant should companytinue to act till a new appointment was made. At this meeting the appellant, as an ex-officio member, was present.

facts.text: Appellant complained to Vice-Chancellor of Bihar University about the appointment.

anchor.surface_text: He alleges that he companyplained about this appointment to the Vice-Chancellor of the Bihar University

facts.text: Vice-Chancellor advised appellant by letter to watch and see what happens.

anchor.surface_text: and he was, by a letter, advised by the Vice-Chancellor to watch and see what happens.

facts.text: Governing Body resolved to advertise Principal post on May 14, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On May 14, 1960 the Governing Body resolved to advertise the post.

facts.text: Appellant present at Governing Body meeting on May 14, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: At this meeting also the appellant was present and on September 26, 1960 the Governing Body resolved to readvertise the post.

facts.text: Governing Body resolved to readvertise Principal post on September 26, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: and on September 26, 1960 the Governing Body resolved to readvertise the post.

facts.text: Candidates including appellant interviewed by Governing Body.

anchor.surface_text: Some candidates including the appellant were interviewed by the Governing Body

facts.text: On December 18, 1960, Governing Body authorized Chairman to select Principal from interviewed candidates including appellant.

anchor.surface_text: and on December 18, 1960 it passed a resolution authorising the Chairman to make a selection from amongst the candidates who had been interviewed, and who included the appellant.

facts.text: President (respondent No. 2) appointed respondent No. 4 as Principal.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with this resolution the President, respondent No. 2, appointed respondent No. 4 as the Principal of the College.

facts.text: Respondent No. 4 was Principal of another College in Bihar at the time of appointment.

anchor.surface_text: He was at that time a Principal of another College in Bihar.

facts.text: On April 18, 1961, appellant asked to hand over charge to new appointee by May 6, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On April 18, 1961 the appellant was asked to hand over charge to the new appointee by May 6, 1961.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 challenging validity of respondent No. 4's appointment.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner thereupon filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the validity of the appointment of respondent No. 4 as Principal

facts.text: Respondents denied petitioner's allegations.

anchor.surface_text: These allegations were denied by the respondents.

facts.text: Resolution of February 23, 1958 not valid as did not consider other teachers for promotion.

anchor.surface_text: They pleaded that the resolution of February 23, 1958 was number valid because it did number companysider the case of other teachers for promotion

facts.text: Appellant's appointment never approved by Syndicate as required by Art. 5 of Statute XVI.

anchor.surface_text: that the appointment of the appellant was never approved by the Syndicate as required by Art. 5 of Statute XVI

facts.text: Appellant applied for Principal post after new resolutions and offered for interview.

anchor.surface_text: that the appellant having himself applied for the post of Principal after the resolutions were passed by the new Governing Body and having offered himself for interview

facts.text: Patna High Court held appellant's appointment not valid as no Syndicate approval.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the appellants appointment was number valid as the Syndicate had number given its approval and the petitioner had been allowed to join the post of Principal without such approval

facts.text: High Court held decision to advertise not punishment, termination or demotion.

anchor.surface_text: that the decision of the Governing Body to advertise for the post of Principal was neither a case of punishment number termination of service number was it a demotion of the appellant,

facts.text: No protest from appellant against new resolution; he submitted for selection.

anchor.surface_text: It also held that there was numberprotest from the appellant against the passing of the new resolution and as he submitted himself for selection,

dismissing the appellants petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: In order that mandamus may issue to compel the respondents to do something it must be shown that the Statutes impose a legal duty and the appellant has a legal right under the Statutes to enforce its performance.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandamus requires demonstration of a statutory legal duty on respondents and corresponding legal right in appellant.

holdings.text: It is wholly unnecessary to go into or decide whether the Statutes framed by the University under s. 20 of University of Bihar Act have the force of law and whether a writ under Art. 226 can issue against the Governing Body.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, wholly unnecessary to go into or decide this question or to decide whether the Statutes impose on the Governing Body of the College a duty which can be enforced by a writ of mandamus because assuming

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issues avoided as resolution turns on absence of enforceable right regardless of these preliminary questions.

holdings.text: Even assuming the College is a public body performing a public duty in appointing a Principal, no right in the appellant enforceable by mandamus has been shown.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical acceptance of public character does not aid appellant absent proof of personal legal right.

holdings.text: The appellant has not shown any right under the Statutes entitling him to an order for appointment or reinstatement as all appointments must be made by Governing Body in accordance with rules.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme vests appointment power in Governing Body per rules; no specific entitlement for appellant proven.

holdings.text: No Article of the Statutes has been shown conferring on the appellant a right to appointment or reinstatement, so he cannot seek a writ.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of cited statutory basis defeats claim to writ relief.

holdings.text: It is therefore not necessary to go into any other question.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Disposition follows from failure to establish legal right; other issues moot.
